topic_rationale: Interstitial lung disease (ILD) can be a challenging diagnosis due to diverse etiologies and overlapping clinical presentations. This puzzle aims to highlight the key features that distinguish idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) from other types of ILD.

explanations.tile_0: Velcro crackles on auscultation are a characteristic finding in patients with IPF, resembling the sound made when separating a Velcro fastener.
explanations.tile_1: Clubbing, a bulbous enlargement of the ends of fingers or toes, is often seen in IPF and signifies advanced disease.
explanations.tile_2: Dry cough is a common symptom of IPF and is often one of the first symptoms.
explanations.tile_3: Dyspnea, particularly on exertion, is a common symptom of IPF and usually progressive.
explanations.tile_4: IPF, by definition, is a form of ILD that occurs without a known cause.
explanations.tile_5: A usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern on high-resolution CT scan is a classic radiologic finding in IPF.
explanations.tile_6: Subpleural fibrosis, or thickening of tissue beneath the pleural surface, is a typical finding in IPF.
explanations.tile_7: Honeycombing on CT, which refers to the appearance of clustered cystic air spaces, is a classic but late feature of IPF.
explanations.tile_8: Exclusion of other ILDs is a part of the diagnostic criteria for IPF.
